p: Small, round virus with high infectivity; <10–100 virus particles are enough to start a gastroenteritis [ 1, 4]. Norovirus (former Norwalk virus) is the cause of “winter vomiting disease” inside and outside institutions, especially winter time (see Fig. 54.1). There is large amount of virus in vomit and faeces (10 12 viruses/gram faeces) during acute disease, and it is rapidly transmitted via vomiting; drops/aerosols; contaminated equipment, textiles, faeces, food and water; etc. [ 1, 4, 7]. Epidemics are especially associated with certain genotypes with more virulent viruses that develop and change over years [ 1, 4].
